img_credit: Own photo, taken at Uppsala Domkyrka.
title: Uppsala stone U 934
description: One of the Uppland inscriptions standing by the Uppsala Domkyrka. It's only a fragmentary stone, but a beautifully decorated. It was excavated from the church grounds in 1866.
explanationAfter: Correct. Inscription reads in modern Swedish as "Tore och Rörik (?) och Karl, de (bröderna)" and in English: "Tore and Rörik (?) and Karl, they brothers...".
sources: A plaque next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieämbetet.

img_credit: Own photo, taken at Uppsala Domkyrka.
title: Uppsala stone U 933
description: The runestone was found in 1866 in the foundation wall of Uppsala Domkyrka. It was carved by runemaster Öpir, who created 5 of 18 known runestones in that church.
explanationAfter: Yes! The inscription reads in Swedish: "Borga lät resa stenen efter Stynbjörn ... Torken lät (resa den) efter sin broder" and in English "Borga had this stone raised after Stynbjörn ... Torken had (it raised) after his brother".
sources: A plaque next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieämbetet.

img_credit: Own photo, taken at Gamla Stan.
title: Gamla Stan stone U 53
description: The runestone (known as U 53) is built into the southeast wall of the house on the corner of Prästgatan and Kåkbrinken at Gamla Stan (Old Town) in Stockholm. The house has a medieval cellar and the stone is believed to have been part of the walls from the house's earliest days. However, it wasn't externally visible until the house's renovation in 18th century. In 1937 the stone was removed from the wall by Riksantikvariet for investigation and inserted again, in a way that makes it better visible and protected.
explanationAfter: Correct! The stone reads "Þor[st]æinn ok Frøygunn þau … stæin æftiʀ …, sun sinn", or in English: "Þorsteinn and Freygunnr, they … stone in memory of … their son".

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Universitetsparken Uppsala.
title: Uppsala stone U 937
description: One of the many runestones standing in Universitetsparken Uppsala, originating from the Viking Age.
runes: ᚦᛁᛅᚴ(ᚾ) × ᛅᚢᚴ × ᚴᚢᚾᛅᚱ × ᚱᛅᛁᛋᛏᚢ × ᛋᛏᛅᚾᛅ × ᛅᚠᛏᛁᛦ × ᚢᛅᚦᚱ × ᛒᚱᚢᚦᚢᚱ ᛋᛁᚾ
explanationAfter: That's correct. This stone translates to: "Þegn and Gunnarr raised the stones in memory of Veðr, their brother".

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Skansen Stockholm.
title: Ölstastenen U 871
description: Rune stone from Uppland (Sweden) carved by Åsmund Kåresson in 11-th century. It can be visited in Skansen on Djursgården, Stockholm. This rune stone was painted in what is believed to be the authentic manner.
runes: ᛒᛁᚾᚱᚾ ᛫ ᛅᚢᚦᚢᛚᚠᚱ ᛫ ᚴᚢᚾᚬᚱ ᛫ ᚼᚢᛚᛘᛏᛁᛋ ᛫ ᛚᛅᛏᚢ ᚱᛁᛏᚬ ᛋᛏᛁᚾ ᚦᛁᚾᚬ ᛫ ᛁᚠᛏᛁᛦ ᛫ ᚢᛚᚠ ᛫ ᚴᛁᚾᛚᛅᚢᚼᛅᛦᛒᚢᛅᚾᛏᛅ ᛫ ᛁᚾᚬᛋᛘᚢᚾᛏᚱᚼᛁᚢ
explanationAfter: Correct. The text translated to modern Swedish is "Björn, Ödulv, Gunnar, Holmdis läto resa denna sten efter Ulv, Ginnlögs man. Och Åsmund högg." And to English: "Björn, Ödulv, Gunnar, Holmdis erected this stone in memory of Ulf, Ginnlög's husband. And Åsmund carved it."
sources: A plaque next to the stone, provided by Skansen Stockholm.

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Skansen Stockholm.
title: Hanstastenen U 72
description: Rune stone from Uppland. One of the four runestones currently stored in Skansen, Stockholm.
runes: ᚴᛁᛅᚱᚦᛅᚱ + ᛅᚢᚴ ᛫ ᛁᚬᚱᚢᚾᛏᚱ ᛫ ᛚᛅᛏᛅ ᛫ ᚱᚽᛁᛋᛅ ᛫ ᚦᛁᛋᛅ ᛫ ᛋᛏᚽᛁᚾᛅ ᛫ ᛁᚠᛏᛁᚱ ᛫ ᛋᛁᛋᛏᚢᚱ ᛫ ᛋᚢᚾᛁ ᛫ ᛋᛁᚾᛅ ᛫ ᛁᚱᚾᛘᚢᚾᛏ x ᛅᚢᚴ ᛫ ᛁᚴᛁᚢᚾᛏ
explanationAfter: Correct. The text translates to modern Swedish as "Gärdar och Jorun låta resa dessa stenar till minne av sina systersöner Ärnmund och Ingemund". And English: "Gärdar and Jorund erected this stone in memory of their nephews Ärnmund and Ingemund".
sources: A plaque next to the stone, provided by Skansen Stockholm.

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Skansen Stockholm.
title: Norslundastenen U 419
description: Rune stone from Uppland. One of the four runestones currently stored in Skansen, Stockholm.
runes: ᚦᛅᚢᚾ ᛫ ᚴᚢᛚᚠᛁᚾᚴᚱ ᛫ ᛅᚢᚴ ᛫ ᛋᛏᛁᚾᚠᚱᛁᚦᚱ ᛫ ᛅᚢᚴ ᛫ ᛋ…ᚱ ᛫ ᛚᛁᛏᚢ ᛫ ᚱᛅᛁᛋᛅ ᛫ ᛋᛏᛁᚾ ᛫ ᚦᛁᚾᚬ ᛫ ᚬᚠᛏᛁᛦ ᛫ ᛅᚢᛋᛏᚾᛁᚾ ᛫ ᚴᚢᚾᛅᚱᛋᚢᚾ ᛫ ᛋ ᛫ ᛅᛏ ᛫ ᛁᚢᚱᛁᛅ ᛫ ᚴᚢᚦ … ᛅᛚᛒᛁ ᛫ ᚼᚬᚾᛋ
explanationAfter: Correct. The text translates to modern Swedish as "Kylving och Stenfrid och Sigfast läto resa denna sten efter Östen, Gunnars son... Gud hjälpe hans själ". And English: "Kylving and Stenfrid and Sigfast erected this stone in memory of Östen, son of Gunnar... May God preserve his soul".
sources: A plaque next to the stone, provided by Skansen Stockholm.

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Norrby, Sweden
title: Norrby stone Sö 272
description: A runestone from the 11th century. It was found in the summer 1915 when ploughing a field. It's currently located next to a roundabout in Norrby, just south of Stockholm.
runes: ᚦᚢᚱᚠᛅᛋᛏᚱ x ᛚᚽᛏ x ᚱᛅᛁ… x ᛋᛏᛅᚽᚾ x ᚦᚽᚾᛅ x ᛅᚠᛏᛁᛦ x ᚼᛅᛚᚠᛏᛅᚾ x ᛋᚢᚾᛅ x ᛋ…ᚾ
explanationAfter: Correct. The stone reads: "Torfast had this stone raised after Halvdan, his son."
sources: A plaque next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieambetet

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Mariefred, Sweden
title: Gripsholm stone Sö 178
description: A rune stone with inscription from the 11th century.
runes: ᚼᛅᚴᚢᛚᚠᚱ x ᛅᚢᚴ x ᛅᚢᛚᚠᚱ x ᚦᛅᛁᛦ x ᛚᛅᛏᚢ x ᚱᛅᛁᛁᛋᛅ x ᛋᛏᛅᛁᚾᛅ x ᛒᛅᚦᛅ x ᛅᛏ x ᛒᚱᚬᚦᚢᚱ x ᛋᛁᚾ x ᚴᛁᛏᛁᛚᛘᚢᛏ x ᛅᚢᚴ x ᛒᚱᚬ x ᛁᚠᛏᛁᛦ x ᛋᚬᛘᚢ x ᛘᚬᚦᚢᚱ x ᛋᛁᚾᛅ x ᛁᛅ x ᛁᚱᚢᚾᛁ x ᛁᛁᚢᚴ x ᛒᚱᚬᚦᛁᛦ x ᚼᛁᚾᛅᛦ
explanationAfter: Correct. The stone reads: "Hälgulv (?) and Oulv they had this stone raised in memory of their brother, Kätilmund, and built a bridge in memory of Soma, their mother. But Brune (?), her brother, carved (the runes)". In Swedish it's a bit more similar to the Old Norse inscription: "Hälgulv (?) och Öulv de läto resa båda stenarna efter sin broder Kätilmund och (gjorde) bro efter Soma, sin moder. Men Brune (?), hennes broder, högg (runorna)".
sources: A plaque next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieambetet

img_credit: https://de.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datei:Right_Gripsholm_Runestone.jpg
title: Gripsholm stone Sö 179
description: The Gripsholm Stone - which can to this day be visited near the Gripsholm Castle not far from Stockholm - is one of the "Ingvarr stones". This group of stones is dated soon after 1041, when the Icelandic annals record the death of Yngvarr the Far-Travelled in the south. Note how the inscriber forgot one word and added it later!
explanationAfter: Correct. The stone was set up by Tola in memory of ther son, Harald. He was Ingvar the Far-travelled's brother. The last part (from the word inserted later) runs: "Þæiʀ foru drængila, fjarri at gulli, auk austarla ærni gafu. Dou sunnarla, a Særklandi" -- "They went manfully, far after gold, and in the east gave [food] to the eagle [i.e. despatched enemies in battle]. They died in the south, in Særkland." (translation credit to Michael P. Barnes, p. 77 from Runes: A Handbook). Ingvar the Far-travelled's expedition to Serkland "the Saracens land" is mentioned on nearly thirty rune stones in the Mälar region.
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 77-8, 81, 139, 169)

img_credit: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kylver_Stone#/media/File:Kylverstenen_1383.jpg
title: Kylver stone G 88
description: The Kylver stone originates from the Baltic island of Gotland. It is one of eleven known inscriptions of the older futhark row, dated to 5th and 6th centuries (only 4 of these 11 give the complete rune row order).
explanationAfter: Two things to note about the Kylver stone: 1) there is no division of the run row into the ættir - groups of eight - unlike for example the Grumpan bracteate; 2) the runes at positions 13-4 (ᛈ, ᛇ) and 23-4 (ᛞ, ᛟ) are given in the opposite order than usually.
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 16-19)

title: Dalängen runestone in Lidingö
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Lidingö.
description: A runestone standing by the road in Lidingö. One of the two present on the island. It was found in 19th century and it has been standing in its current place since 1943.
runes: ᚴᚬᚱᛁ x ᛅᚢᚴ x ᛁᛅᚴᛚᛏᚱ x ᛅᚢ … ᛁᚱ ᛫ ᛒᛁᛁᚱᚾ ᛫ ᚠᛅᚦᚢᚱ ᛫ ᛋᛁᚾ ᛫ ᚴᚢᚦ ᛫ …
explanationAfter: The remaining part of the stone can be read as "Kore and Ingjald and ... after Björn, their father. God ...". It seems to follow a standard formula, helping us fill the gaps: "Kore and Ingjald raised this stone after Björn, their father. God help...".
sources: Info table next to the stone, provided by Stockholms Läns Museum and Lidingö Stad

title: Askrikevägen rune slab in Lidingö
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Lidingö.
description: This memorial inscription belongs to an iron-age burial place, consisting of a bit over 50 graves. It is one of the two runestones on the island.
runes: ᛅᛋᛘᚢᚾᛏ ᚱ… ᚱᚢᚾᛁᛦ ᚽᚠᛏᛁᛦ ᛋᛏᚽᛁᚾ ᚠᛅᚦᚢᚱᛋ ᚠᛅᚦᚢᚱ ᛋᛁᚾ ᛅᚢᚴ ᚠᛅᚦᚢᚱ ᛋᛁᛒᛅ ᛅᚴ ᚴᚽᛁᛦᛒᛁᛅᚱᚾᛅᛦ ᛅᚮᚴ ᚢᛚᚠᛋ ᚽᛅᛦᛘᚽᚱᚴᛁ ᛘᛁᚴᛁᛏ ᛅᛏ ᛘᛅᚾ ᚴᚮᚦᛅᚾ
explanationAfter: Correct! The translation to Swedish goes: "Åsmund ristade runor efter Sten, sin farfar, och fadern till Sibbe och Gerbjörn och Ulf. Här ett stort minnesmärke efter en god man" and to English: "Aasmund carved runes after Sten, his grandfather and father of Sibbe and Gerbjorn and Ulf. Here is a big memorial to a good man." From the description, we cannot tell whether Sten lies at the same location as the inscription. A big cross being part of the inscription suggests that Sten converted to christianity.
sources: Info table next to the stone, provided by Lidingö Stad

title: Bjärby stone Ö 36
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Bjärby
description: A beautiful 11-century runestone standing by the side of the road in Bjärby in eastern Öland, Sweden.
runes: ᚼᛁᚱᚠᚱᛁ…ᚢᛁᚦᛒᛁᚢᚱᚾ x ᛚᛁᛏᚢ x ᚱᛅᛁᛋᛅ x ᛋᛏᛅᛁᚾ x ᚦᛁᚾᛅ x ᛅᛏ x ᚠᛅ…ᛏᚢᛚᚠ x ᚠᛅᚦᚢᚱ x ᛋᛁᚾ ᛋᛁᚴᛚᛅᚢᚴ x ᛚᛁᛏ x ᚱᛅᛁᛋᛅ x ᛅᚠᛏᛁᛦ x ᛒᚢᚾᛏᛅ x ᛋᛁᚾ x ᚼᛅᚾ x ᛁᛅᚱ x ᚴᚱᛅᚠᛁᚾᛁ x ᚴᛁᚱᛁᚴᛁᚢ
explanationAfter: Correct! Swedish translation provided onsite: "Härfrid och Vidbjörn läto resa stenen efter Fastul sin fader. Siglaug lät resa efter sin make. Han är begraven i kyrkan." In English that would be: "Harfrid and Vidbjorn had this stone raised after their father Fastul. Siglaug had it raised after her husband. He is buried in the church."
sources: Info table next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieambetet.

title: Gårdby stone Ö 28
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Gårdby
description: A well preserved 11-th century runestone, now standing in the cemetery in Gårdby, Öland.
runes: ᚼᛅᚱᚦᚱᚢᚦᚱ x ᚱᛅᛁᛋᛁ x ᛋᛏᛅᛁᚾ x ᚦᛁᚾᛋᛅ x ᛅᚠᛏᛁᛦ x ᛋᚢᚾ x ᛋᛁᚾ x ᛋᛘᛁᚦ x ᛏᚱᛅᚴ x ᚴᚢᚦᛅᚾ x ᚼᛅᛚᚠᛒᚢᚱᛁᚾ x ᛒᚱᚢᚦᛁᚱ x ᛋᛁᚾ x ᛋᛁᛏᚱ x ᚴᛅᚱ ᚦᚢᛘ ᛒᚱᛅᚾᛏᚱ ᚱᛁᛏᛁ ᛁᛅᚴᚦᚢ ᚱᛅᚦᛅ ᚴᚼᚾ
explanationAfter: Yes! Swedish translation: "Härtrud reste denna sten efter sin son Smed, en god man. Halvboren, hans broder, sitter i Gårdarike. Brand högg rätt, därför kan du tyda." English: "Hartrud raised this stone after his son Smed, a good man. Halvbor, his brother, is in Gaardarike. Brand (sword?) cut straight, therefore you can decipher". Gårdarike is an old Norse name for the Swedish viking areas in current Russia.
sources: Info table next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieambetet.

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Historiska Museet
title: Picture stone from Stånga
description: Picture stone with runic inscription in a ribbon shape. At the top there is an indoor scene with a man and woman sitting opposite one another on a seat of honour. Behind the man, but outisde the walls of the room, there is the triquetra, also known as valknut. Another figure is approaching the man and presenting or taking a spear. The woman appears to be watching what is happening, but behind her a longnecked, bird-like creature is sticking in its head and pecking the standing man in the back. The scene below depicts three male figures, marching in a line carrying a spear, a sickle and a club or torch. Behind them there is a circular shape and beneath it something that could be a flaming fire. One interpretation is that the scene depicts a "cadastral survey", perhaps at full moon on the vernal equinox. Others have interpreted the three men as Odin, Thor and Frey. The stone was found in Stånga Parish in Gotland.
explanationAfter: Correct! The inscription runs "Rodvisl and Farbjörn and Gunbjörn"

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Historiska Museet
title: Uppland stone U 614
description: One of the two runestones (the other being U 613) which originally stood at the boundary of what later became known as Torsätra Herrgård but which during the Viking Age was called Husa. Both stones were moved to the Swedish History Museum in 1967. The ornamentation, the appearance of the runes and the inscription all indicate that the stone was engraved by Visäte, sometime during the latter decades of the 11th century. The stone is on display in Historiska Museet in Stockholm.
explanationAfter: Correct! The text translates to Swedish as: "Skule och Folke låt resa denna sten efter sin broder Husbjörn. Han blev sjuk ute då de togo gäld på Gotland." And to English: "Skull och Folki raised this stone in memory of their brother Husbjorn. He fell ill while collecting payment on Gotland." Husbjorn took part in a voyage from the mainland to the island to collect "geld" or tax. This tallies with a part of the medieval Gutasagan which tells of an old agreement between the Gutes and the Svear. The agreement stipulated that the Svear had the right to collect 60 marks of silver in geld (tax/tribute) from Gotland each year. 40 marks would go to the King and 20 to the Jarl. In return the Gutes would be given protection against attack and raids and the right to indulge in free trade with the Svear in their seas.

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Historiska Museet
title: Unna's stone U 613
description: One of the two rune stones (the other being U 614) which originally stood at the boundary of what later became known as Torsätra Herrgård but which during the Viking Age was called Husa. The inscription starts on the right side of the stone and runs downwards and inside the head of the serpent from where it continues on the other side.
runes: ᚢᚾᛅ + ᛚᛁᛏ + ᚱᚽᛁᛋᛅ + ᚦᛁᚾᛋᛅ + ᛋᛏᚽᛁᚾ + ᛅᚠᛏᛦ + ᛋᚢᚾᛋᛁᚾ + ᛁᛋᛏᛁᚾ + ᛋᚢᛘ + ᛏᚬ + ᛁᚼᚬᛁᛏᛅ + ᚢᛅᚦᚢᛘ + ᚴᚢᚦᚼᛁᛅᛚᛒᛁ + ᛋᛅᛚᚢ + ᚼᛅᚾᛋ
explanationAfter: Correct. The inscription runs: "'Unna had this stone raised in memory of his son Östen, who died wearing a christening gown. God preserve his soul." ("Unna let ræisa þennsa stæin æftiʀ sun sinn Øystæin, sum do i hvitavaðum. Gud hialpi salu hans.")

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Lerkaka
title: Lerkaka stone Ö 37
description: An 11-century runestone standing by the road in Lerkaka, just across the beautiful windmills.
runes: ᚬᛚᛅᚠᛦ x ᛅᚢᚴ x ᚴᛅᛘᛅᛚ x ᛅᚢᚴ x ᛋᛅᚴᛋᛁ x ᚱᛅᛁᛋᛏᚢ x ᛋᛏᛅᛁᚾ x ᚦᛁᚾᛅ x ᛅᚠᛏᛁᛦ…ᚢᛁᛚᛁᛏ x ᛅᛏ x ᛒᚬᚾᛏᛅ x ᛋᛁᚾ x ᚼᛁᛅᚱᛋᚢ…ᚴᚢᛒᛚᚦᛋᛁᚠᛁᛅᛦᚢᚾᚬᛚᛅᚠᛦᚼᚽᚠᚾᛏ…ᚠᛅᚾᛒᚢ
explanationAfter: Yes! The full stone originally said: "Olof and Gammal and Saxe raised this stone after their father, Unn. Geirvi had this memorial made after her husband. Olof avenged Rike-Unn at Miomu. Unn owned half the village." (in Swedish: "Olof och Gammal och Saxe reste denna sten efter Unn, sin fader. Geirvi lät efter sin make här (göra) denna minnesvård. För Rike-Unn hämnades Olof vid Miomu; Unn ägde här halva byn.")
sources: A plaque next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieambetet

title: Norum font
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Historiska Museet
runes: ᛌᚢᛅᚾᚴᛅᚱᚦᚽ ᛘᛁᚴ ᛘᛁᚴ ᛘᛁᚴ ᛘᛁᚴ ᛘᛁᚴ
description: Soapstone baptismal font, found in 1847 in a scrap heap in the cemetery of Norum Church. All four sides are decorated, one side contains a runic inscription.
explanationAfter: Indeed, the inscription says: "Sven made me" ("Sven gjorde mig"). The last 5 characters seem to be bind runes for "mik" or "mig" - "me".

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Historiska Museet
title: Rune stone fragment from Össeby
description: The fragment was found in the longhouse in Össeby-garn parish, Uppland, Sweden.
explanationAfter: The preserved fragment of inscription suggests the following interpretation: "monument in memory of Ingevald, his [her] son".

img_credit: Own photo, taken at Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands.
description: The runestick was found during archeological excavations in Durhúsi in Eiði. Runologically, the inscription is dated to 900-1200 AD. Archeological observations point to the elder part of this period.
title: Eiði runestick
explanationAfter: Indeed, the stick contains first 13 rune characters of short-twig Younger Fuþark, which were used in North Western areas, including Faroes.
sources: Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands

img_credit: Own photo, taken at Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands.
title: Sandavágur rune-stone
description: This is the most magnificent rune-stone inscription found in the Faroes. The stone was found by chance, at the abandoned ancient settlement í Eingjartoftum in Sandavágur in 1917. You can see this to this day in Sandavágur church. The runes are of the younger Swedo-Norwegian type.
explanationAfter: Good! The translation provided by Tjóðsavnið is: "1. þorkæl onondarsun 2. austmaþrafruha 3. lande bygþe þe(n) 4. a saþ fyst". In English: "Torkil Onundarson from Rogaland was the first to settle this place."
sources: Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands

img_credit: Own photo, taken at Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands.
title: Sørvágur wooden box
description: This box orignates from the Sørvágur village in the Vágar island.
explanationAfter: The latin alphabet has been carved with runes, supplemented by the date ANNO 1695. G. I. S. below stands for G(utti) J(oens) S(on).
sources: Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands

img_credit: Own photo, taken at the Bryggen Museum, Bergen.
title: Bergen stick B 149
description: The stick was found in archeological excavations in the Bryggen district of Bergen, following a fire in 1955. It has an inscription on both sides. The first side says: ᚴᛦᛆ : ᛌᛅᚼᛁᚱ : ᛆᛐᚦᚢ : ᚴᛆᚴ : ᚼᛅᛁᛉ.
explanationAfter: Yes! That is a famous inscription which translates to "Gyða segir at þú gakk heim" - "Gyða tells you to go home"! Funnily enough, the inscription on the second side is incomprehensible - perhaps the respondent of the message was in a tavern and was either not very literate or already drunk, when he tried to respond to Gyða.

title: Possible gravestone from Bryggen, Bergen
img_credit: Own photo, taken at the Bryggen Museum, Bergen.
description: This stone is dated to 1248-1332 and was possibly a gravestone.
explanationAfter: Correct. The inscription was interpreted as: "Arne carved this. Erik bakium (a nickname?) carved this the night before..." ("Dette ristet Arne. Dette ristet Eirik bakium natten f...").
sources: Description in the Bryggen Museum, Bergen.

title: Bergen knife beater
img_credit: Own photo, taken at the Bryggen Museum, Bergen.
description: A medieval knife beater from Bryggen, Bergen.
explanationAfter: The inscription runs "Håkon carved me, but the boy owns me." (Norwegian: "Håkon ristet meg, men sveinen eier meg.") There is additional inscription on the other side, saying: "Bård owns me. He found much to object to in the person who carved me."
sources: Description in the Bryggen Museum, Bergen.

title: Eik stone
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the Arkeologisk museum | University of Stavanger.
description: The Eik stone was found in the river Sokna. Originally it was placed by a bridge. The inscription is dated to the first half of the 11th century.
explanationAfter: The inscription tells us who build the bridge: "Sakse made, giving thanks to God, this bridge for the soul of his mother, Turid" ("Sakse gjorde, for Guds takk, denne brua for sjela til mora si, Turid.")

title: Stone inscription from Møgedal Eigersund
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the Arkeologisk museum | University of Stavanger.
description: The inscription is written in older runes and is dated to ca. 500 AD.
explanationAfter: The runes probably represent a man's name.

title: Hobro rune stone
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the public library in Hobro
description: A granit rune stone dated to 970-1020.
explanationAfter: The stone is transliterated as: "Thurir risthi stin tháasi aufti Karl hin kuthaa fælaka sin harta a kutháan træk". In Danish: "Thore rejste denne sten efter sin fælle Karl den Gode, en meget god dreng". Finally, in English: "Thore raised this stone after his friend Carl the Good, a very good guy". Confusingly, the "ᛦ" rune, normally denoting "r", is used also as "æ" in several words. This type of laying out letters on a runestone is typical for Jutland and Skåne. We know of one more stone raised possibly by the same Thore - the Glenstrup 1 stone.

title: Glenstrup 1 rune stone
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Copenhagen
description: A rune stone from Glenstrup, dated to around 1000 AD.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into Danish as: "Thore rejste denne sten efter sin fader Gunnar" and English: "Thore raised this stone in memory of Gunnar, his father". This type of laying out letters on a runestone is typical for Jutland and Skåne. We know of one more stone raised possibly by the same Thore - the Hobro stone.

title: Glenstrup 2 rune stone
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the Glenstrup church
description: Glenstrup 2 stone is also known as Handeststenen, since it used to be located in the Handest church, which no longer exists. Then it was used as a part of the foundation for a turf house. Finally, it was moved to Glenstrup in 1881. The photo below shows the front of the stone, but the last few runes are on the side. At the back of the stone, there is a carving of a deer. The red paint on the carvings has been filled by the conservators from Danish National Museum.
sources: A pamphlet from the Glenstrup church
explanationAfter: The inscription translates very similarly to Danish: "Toke satte denne sten efter sin far Ufla en hard god thegn". In English: "Toki raised this stone after his father Ufla, a rich and good landowner."

title: Læborg stone
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Læborg
description: A large granit rune stone standing in Læborg. Runic inscriptions run on two sides and it is decorated with two hammers (presumably Thor's).
sources: Gåden om Thyra show on DRTV
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into Danish as: "Ravnunga-Tove hug runer disse efter Tyre, dronning sin." English: "Ravnunga-Tove carved these runes after Thyra, his queen." Who was Thyra? She was a powerful figure, who's named also on both Jelling stones and the Bække 1 stone. Ravnunge-Tove (or -Tue) is named also on Bække 1 stone and Bække 2 stone.

title: Bække 1 stone
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Bække
description: A runestone found in Bække in 1820. It was brought to its current honourable placing in 1923, as the construction of church's tower has was completed.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into Danish as: "Ravnunge-Tue og Fundin og Gnyple, de tre gjorde Thyras høj". In English: "Ravnunge-Tue and Fundin and Gnyple, they three made Thyras monument." Who was Thyra? She was a powerful figure, who's named also on both Jelling stones and the Læborg stone. Ravnunge-Tue (or -Tove) is named also on Læborg stone and Bække 2 stone.

title: Bække 2 stone
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Bække
description: The runic stone was erected in the 900s. It constitutes a part (in fact, a stem) of a stone ship near Klebæk Høje. Stone ships were often, though not always, built around graves. The stone ship at Klebæk Høje (also known as the Bække Monument) is 45 meters long and dates back to the Viking Age. It is flanked by two Bronze Age burial mounds.
sources: Gåden om Thyra show on DRTV
explanationAfter: The inscription states: "Ravnunge-Tue made these monuments for his mother Vibrog" (Danish: "Ravnunge-Tue gjorde disse kumler [mindesmærker] efter sin moder Vibrog."). Unlike the other two nearby stones signed Ravnunge-Tue (Bække 1 and Læborg stones), this one is hard to read, due to abbreviated words and missing separators between words. Either way, Ravnunge-Tue was clearly an important figure in the local community.

title: Gorm's stone in Jelling
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Jelling
description: On this stone, the name Denmark appears for the first time within the country. The stone was placed in c. 950 by Gorm the Old. It is the smaller of the two iconic Jelling stones. They stand to this day at the location of Jelling monument, an enormous show of power consisting of two grave mounds, and a gigantic grave ship surrounded by a 1.4 km long palisade.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into modern Danish as: "Kong Gorm gjorde disse kumler (monumenter) efter Thyra sin kone - Danmarks pryd". And to English: "King Gorm made this monument to Thyra, his wife, Denmark's adornment". Little is known about Thyra, apart from her name appearing on four different runestones, praising her as wife and queen.

title: Harald's stone in Jelling
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Jelling
description: The bigger of the two Jelling stones, raised by Harald Bluetooth, the son of Gorm. The stone dates back to around 965, to a time when Denmark was transitioning from a tribal society to a Christian kingdom.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered to modern Danish as: "Kong Harald bød gøre disse kumler (monumenter) efter Gorm sin fader og efter Thyra sin moder. Den Harald som vandt sig hele Danmark og Norge og gjorde Danerne kristne." And in English: "King Harald had these monuments raised after his father Gorm and after his mother Thyra. Harald, who united all of Denmark and Norway and christened the Danes." This stone is considered the Denmark's birth certificate.

title: Aarhus mask stone DR 66 (Mjy77)
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the musem
description: The "mask stone" from Aarhus, dating from around AD 970-1020. It was found in 1850, in the foundations of the mill Aarhus Mølle.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into modern Danish as: "Gunulv og Øgot og Aslak og Rolf rejste denne sten efter deres fælle Ful. Han fandt døden ... da konger kæmpede". In English: "Gunnulfr and Eygautr/Auðgautr and Áslakr and Hrólfr raised this stone in memory of Fúl, their partner, who died when kings fought". Perhaps it is a reference to the battle at Svolder, a naval battle in AD 1000, when the Danish king Swein Forkbeard, the Swedish king Olof Skötkonung and the Norwegian earl Eirik Hákonarson fought the Norwegian king Olaf Tryggvason.

title: Aarhus Runestone DR 67 (MJy78)
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the museum
description: Runestone dated around AD 1000, found in 1866 beneath Vor Frue Kirke (church of Our Lady) in Aarhus.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into modern Danish as: "Kaeld rejste denne sten efter sin fader Inge." In English: "Ketill raised this stone in memory of Ingi, his father".

title: Aarhus Runestone DR 68 (MJy79)
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the museum
description: Rune stone from around AD 1000. Found in 1905 in the foundations of Vor Frue Kirke (church of Our Lady) in Aarhus. The inscription runs on two sides of the stone. One side (the continuation of the text) is also ornamented.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into modern Danish as: "Toste og Hove rejste sammen med Fredbjørn denne sten efter Asser Saxe, deres fælle, en meget velbyrdig dreng. Han døde som den største unidding blandt mænd. Han ejede skib sammen med Arne". In English: "Tosti and Hofi and Freybjorn raised this stone in memory of Azurr Saxon/Sword(-wielder), their partner, a very good 'drengr'. He died as the most unvillainous of men. He owned a ship with Arni". Asser Saxe was clearly a respected figure. The term drengr is a noble title and unvillainous simply means an honourable man. The statement that Asser owned a ship with Arne could mean that they ran a trading company together.

title: Aarhus Runestone DR 69 (MJy73)
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the museum
description: Rune stone dating back to AD 1000, found north of Aarhus in the 17th century.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into modern Danish as: "Thydkill rejste denne sten efter sin måg Thue". In English: "Þjöðkell raised this stone in memory of Tófi, his måg". Måg is a male relation by marriage - a brother- or father-in-law.

title: The Hørning stone DR 58
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the museum
description: Runestone dating around AD 1000, found in 1849 in Hørning, southwest of Aarhus, next to the old road between Jelling and Aarhus. A copy of this stone stands in the Viking Museum in Aarhus.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into modern Danish as: "Toke Smed rejste stenen efter Troels Gudmunds søn, som gav ham guld(?) og frihed". In English: "Toki Smith raised the stone in memory of Þorgist Guðmundr's son, who gave him gold(?) and freedom".

title: Asferg stone DR 121 (MJy 47)
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the National Museum of Denmark
description: Rune stoned dated around AD 1000.
explanationAfter: The transcription in Danish runs: "Thorger Tokes søn rejste denne sten efter sin broder Mule, en meget god thegn". In English: "Thorger Toke's son raised this stone in memory of Mule, his brother, a very good thegn".

title: Snoldelev stone DR 248
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the National Museum of Denmark
description: Rune stone dated to 8th-9th century AD. Apart from the inscription, contains two ornaments: three interlaced horns and a fylfot.
explanationAfter: This older stone is tricky to transliterate as it is written in the early form of younger futhark. For example, 'ᚼ' denotes 'a' instead of 'h', and two words blend together (kunualts stain = kunualtstain). It is rendered into Danish as: "Gunvalds sten, søn af Roald, thul (taler, fremsigemand?) i Salløv (på Salhøjene)". In English: "Gunvald's stone, son of Roald, thul (speaker, reciter?) in Salløv (on the Salmounds)".

title: Tirsted stone DR 216
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the National Museum of Denmark
description: A rune stone dated to 10th century AD.
explanationAfter: The inscription is rendered into modern Danish as: "Asråd og Hildvig (eller Hildulv?) rejste denne sten efter Frede, deres frænde (?), men han var (da mænds skræk?), og han døde i Svitjod (Sverige) og var (først i Frigges skare?), derefter alle vikingerne." In English: "Asråd and Hildvig  Hildulv?) raised this stone in memory of Frede, their kinsman (?). And he was then (the terror of man?), and he died in Svitjod (Sweden) and was (the foremost of Frigge's host?). And then: all viking". As you see, it's very hard to interpret.

title: Stone at the Viking Museum Ladby
img_credit: Own photo, taken in Ladby
description: A modern stone at the parking of the Ladby Viking Museum.
explanationAfter: The inscription says: "Velkomin til Ladby Skibet. Fare hel og vel" - "Welcome to the Ladby ship. Travel whole and well!" There is indeed a 1000-year old ship burial next to the museum, left in its original location and shape. It's truly worth paying a visit there.

title: A wooden spade from Iceland
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the National Museum of Iceland
description: A wooden spade with runes cut into the blade. It was found in a peat bog and dates from the 12th century. It can be seen in Iceland's national museum.
explanationAfter: Correct. The inscription has been interpreted as "boalliatmik inkialtr kærþi", in modern Icelandic: "Páll lét mig (gera), Ingjaldur gerði (mig)" and in English: "Páll had me (made), Ingjaldur made (me)".

title: Bergþórshvoll stick
img_credit: Own photo, taken in the National Museum of Iceland
description: A rune-inscribed stick said to have been unearthed in 1925 at the farm Bergþórshvoll in the south of Iceland. On one side it has a list of runes in roman alphabet order from a to u and on the other... Solve the exercise to find out!
explanationAfter: The runes form a formula "sator:aripo:tinit:opira:rotas", widely quoted in the medieval Europe (though originating in earlier period). The formula is a palindrome with some interesting patterns, also known as Sator Square. The stick is dated late, to seventeenth or eighteenth century.

img_credit: Own photo, taken in The Einar Jónsson Museum
title: Thorfinn Karlsefni sculpture
description: This very modern usage of runes is the back of Einár Jónsson's sculpture of Þorfinnur Karlsefni from 1918. Þorfinnur Karlsefni was an Icelandic sailor, who journeyed to Vinland, previously discovered by Leif Eriksson.
explanationAfter: Correct. The inscription runs "Frá eylandi norðurs elds og ísa / blómstrandi dala og blárra fjalla / vakandi sólar og draumadimmu / dísa heimkynni norðurljósa" (in English: "From the northern isle of fire and ice / of verdant dales and blue mountains / of wakeful sun and dreaming dark / abode of the goddesses of the Northern Lights"). It is a description of Thorfinn's home country.
runes: ᚠᚱᚨ ᛖᛁᛚᚨᚾᛞᛁ : ᚾᛟᚱᛞᚢᚱᛋ ᛖᛚᛞᛋ ᛟᚷ ᛁᛋᚨ | ᛒᛚᛟᛗᛋᛏᚱᚨᚾᛞᛁ : ᛞᚨᛚᚨ ᛟᚷ ᛒᛚᚨᚱᚱᚨ ᚠᛃᚨᛚᛚᚨ | …ᚨᚾᛞᛁ ᛋᛟᛚᚨᚱ ᛟᚷ : ᛞᚱᚨᚢᛗᚨᛞᛁᛗᛗᚢ | ᛞᛁᛋᚨ ᚼᛖᛁᛗᛃᚢᚾᚾᛁ : ᚾᛟᚱᛞᚢᚱᛚᛁᛟᛋᚨ

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Borgarnes
title: Grave mound in Borgarnes
description: A modern inscription from a grave mound in Borgarnes of one of the first Icelandic settlers. The entire park is dedicated to his memory.
explanationAfter: Of course, that's Skalla-Grim Kveld-Ulfsson! Although he died of old age at his farm Borg at Myrar, he is said to be buried in Borgarnes.
sources: An information board provided by the Borgarnes commune authorities

title: Assasin's Creed Valhalla loading screen
description: This text is looped twice around the game logo in the loading screen of Assasin's Creed Valhalla.
runes: ᛏᛅᚢᛦ ᚠᛁ ᛏᛅᚢᛁᛅ ᚠᚱᚬᛏᛦ ᛏᛅᚢᛦ ᛋᛁᛅᛚᚠᛦ ᛁᛏ ᛋᛅᛘᛅ ᛁᚴ ᚢᛅᛁᛏ ᛅᛁᚾ ᛅᛏ ᛅᛚᛏᚱᛁ ᛏᛅᚢᛦ ᛏᚢᛘᛦ ᚢᛒ ᛏᛅᚢᚦᛅᚾ ᚼᚢᛅᚱᚾ
explanationAfter: This text is an excerpt from Havamal - stanza 77 to be precise: "deyr fé, deyja frændr, deyr sjalfr it sama, ek veit einn, at aldrei deyr: dómr um dauðan hvern". In Carolyne Larringtone's translation: "Cattle die, kinsmen die, the self must also die; I know one thing which never dies; the reputation of each dead man."

img_credit: https://adventuretime.fandom.com/wiki/Runic_code#Guitar_banner_in_"Five_More_Short_Graybles"
title: Adventure Time: runic banner from "Five More Short Graybles"
description: This is a banner from an episode "Five More Short Graybles" written in Older Futhark.
explanationAfter: Indeed, that's a guitar repair shop! Note how they used the thorn rune wrongly, as "p" instead of "th".

img_credit: https://adventuretime.fandom.com/wiki/Runic_code#Pitcher_in_"Video_Makers"
title: Adventure Time: a cup from "Video Makers"
description: A message on a cup from which Finn pours drinks in the "Video Makers" episode. It appears to be in the Anglo-Saxon runic system.
explanationAfter: Correct! Note the wrong usage of the thorn rune as "p" instead of "th". The authors intended to spell "Cup of many ale".

img_credit: https://adventuretime.fandom.com/wiki/Runic_code#Sword_in_"Web_Weirdos"
title: Adventure Time: a sword from "Web Weirdos"
description: This magic sword appears in an episode "Web weirdos".
explanationAfter: Yes! The sword says "I am a skeleton I wish I had skin".

img_credit: https://adventuretime.fandom.com/wiki/Runic_code#Staff_in_"Storytelling"
title: Adventure Time: a staff from "Storytelling"
description: This secret message appears on the staff of the Forest Wizard in the "Storytelling" episode when he bashes Finn on the head with it. The image is flipped horizontally.
explanationAfter: Yes, it spells FACE.

img_credit: https://adventuretime.fandom.com/wiki/Runic_code#Sword_in_"Morituri_Te_Salutamus"
title: Adventure Time: a sword from "Morituri Te Salutamus"
description: A sword that occurs in the episode "Morituri Te Salutamus"
explanationAfter: Indeed, the runic message says "To fight is to live". While the use of Uruz rune for "v" is historically common, the choice of ᚹ for "h" is more surprising.
